frontmatter.description: Derivation of Dirac distribution from Fourier Transform identity.
frontmatter.title: Dirac Distribution and Fourier Transform

node.rawBody: --- title: Dirac Distribution and Fourier Transform date: "2020-12-30" description: "Derivation of Dirac distribution from Fourier Transform identity." tags: ["dirac-distributions", "fourier-transform"] --- The standard definition of Fourier transform is defined by $$ \mathcal{F}(p) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^\infty dx \; f(x) e^{-ipx} $$ and its inverse is defined by $$ f(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^\infty dp \; \mathcal{F}(p) e^{ipx} $$ With a small trick of combining the above, we obtain $$ f(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^\infty dp \; \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^\infty dx' \; f(x') e^{-ipx'} e^{ipx} $$ $$ f(x) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty dx' \; f(x') \; \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_{-\infty}^\infty dp \; e^{ip(x-x')} $$ The integral on the right has the property of a Dirac delta distribution, $\int dx\;f(x')\delta(x-x') = f(x)$. This suggests the identity $$ \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_{-\infty}^\infty dp \; e^{ip(x-x')} = \delta(x-x') $$ This is not a proof however. In order to derive it more rigorously, recall Dirac's delta is a distribution. Consider the following implementation of the distribution, $$ \delta(x-x') = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \delta_n(x-x') = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sqrt{\frac{n}{\pi}} e^{-n(x-x')^2} $$ The requirement that $\int dx \delta_n(x-x') = 1$ for all $n$ is satisfied. It can be shown that $$ \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sqrt{\frac{n}{\pi}} e^{-n(x-x')^2} = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{2\pi} \int dp \;e^{-\frac{p^2}{4n}} e^{i(x-x')p} \rightarrow \frac{1}{2\pi} \int dp \; e^{i(x-x')p} $$ Thus we have the identity $$ \delta(x-x') = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int dp \; e^{i(x-x')p} $$
